Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Case-Control Studies, New Directions and Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
Case-control studies mark possibly the single most important and far-reaching contribution that statisticians have made in the domain of Public Health and Epidemiology. The prime objective of this research is to make some new contributions to case-control studies, both in methodology and in application. In particular, the PIs propose a semiparametric Bayesian method to incorporate longitudinal data in a case-control analysis using penalized splines. New Bayesian functional data-analytic tools are needed here. The methods will be applied to biomarker based screening procedures, and will provide a critical appraisal of the association between prostate cancer and the past trajectory of prostate-specific antigen measurements. A second component of the proposed research is the analysis of case-control data generated from two-phase sampling with non-monotone missingness in covariates. Such designs have many potential applications in case-control studies that explore interplay of genetic and environmental risk factors. Exploiting assumptions like gene-gene and gene-environment independence adds to the complexity of the inference. The methods are motivated by an immediate application to a large population based case-control study of colorectal cancer. The final aspect of this proposal deals with a united methodology which provides equivalent inference for odds ratio parameters based on prospective and retrospective models. Both frequentist and Bayesian methods will be considered. The PIs have a track record of successful collaboration in this domain, and want to advance/ extend their work further in these new directions.

Two scientific streams are currently dominating clinical medicine and public health: the molecular biology approach with an emphasis on genetics and discovery of novel biomarkers, and the quantitative approach with an emphasis on epidemiology. The developments in these areas jointly are making fundamental contributions to the study of etiology, diagnosis, prognosis and treatment of complex diseases. Though the standard unmatched case-control study design still remains one of the most popular epidemiologic tools, phenomenal advancement of medical science and genetic technology is giving rise to many complex design and analysis issues which statisticians and epidemiologists have never confronted before. This proposal lies in that new interface of epidemiology and statistics. To understand the mechanism of complex diseases and to design targeted intervention strategies for high-risk individuals is one of the major areas of scientific research in this century. The current proposal is not a mere academic pursuit but an effort to contribute to this scientific process.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Case-control studies are a dominant form of analytical research in epidemiology, especially in cancer epidemiology. The funded project contributed to development of statistical methods for better use of all available sources of data under case-control and variants of case-control sampling. For example, we illustrated how to use longitudinal data available on past exposure history in a nested case-control study. We illustrated the effect of having information on cumulative exposure and lifetime expsoure history is better than having exposure data collected at a single point of time. We also considered Bayesian inference for case-crossover studies and two-phase studies that occur commonly in environmental and genetic epidemiology. We illustrated various advantages of our proposed methods in terms of efficiency and robustness. The proposal also contributed to new theory on equivalence of posterior inference under case-control and case-crossover studies.

Most human diseases have a multifactorial etiology involving complex interplay of genetic and environmental risk factors. Case-control studies are often used to characterize such "gene-environment interactions". For example, smoking does not have the same effect on each individual as far as lung cancer suspectibility is concerned, thus it is reasonable to postulate that an individual's genetic make-up can modify the effect of smoking on lung cancer risk. Supported by the funding of this grant, we conducted several studies to compare existing techniques for screening for gene-environmnent interactions.  These studies will guide practitioners as they embark on their search for gene-environment interaction in large case-control studies and meta-analysis of case-control studies.

 

The proposal generated not only new research, but new researchers. Graduate students supported by the grant are currently pursuing their own research career in academia as faculty members. The software developed were distributed to the PI's website. Presentations were made at national and international meetings. Workshops and tutorials were offered at several venues to disseminate the new knowledge.

The work in the proposal was closely tied to several ongoing studies. We used data from the Molecular epidemiology of colorectal cancer study in Northern Israel to understand the disease etiology of colorectal cancer. We characterized how use of statins and genes on the cholesterol metabolism, lipid synthesis pathway contribute jointly to manifest a chemoprotective association in colorectal cancer. We used data from the Detroit Medicaid database to characterize association of air pollution and asthma in pediatric polpulation. We used data from the Normative Aging Study, a longitudinal study of Boston area veterans to characterize association of disease outcomes related to hypertension, diabetes and obesity with exposure to heavy metals and toxicants in the environment. We illustrated how this adverse effect can be modified by genotype status of certain genes important in the exposure pathway. We used data from Ecuador on incidence of diarrheal diseases and studied several individual and community level factors in the disease transmission process.

In summary, the funded research was highly integrated with public health problems that are relevant to global human health and created an impact in the interface of molecular biology, statistics, epidemiology and environmental health sciences.
